sn46.5:1.2: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn46.5:1.4: How are the awakening factors defined?”
sn46.5:1.5: “Mendicant, they’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.
sn46.5:1.6: A mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,
sn46.5:1.7: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
sn46.5:1.8: As they develop the seven awakening factors, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
sn46.5:1.9: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn46.5:1.10: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
sn46.5:1.11: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.”
